In an early scene with Evan Rachel Wood, who plays Westworldâ€™s oldest robotic host, Dolores Abernathy, for example, a suited-up Wright calmly asks her, â€œDo you remember our last conversation, Dolores?â€ She looks at him sweetly, responding, â€œYes, of course.â€ At the time, Wood assumed this was a typical programming exchange between her character and Bernard. By the end of the season, however, the actress realized sheâ€™d been acting across multiple timelines â€• that Wright had at times been playing Bernard and at other times Arnold. Slight shifts in Wrightâ€™s personality and wardrobe, and each sceneâ€™s setting, artfully camouflaged the reveal. â€œNo one knew until they got the script of the seventh episode, and then texts were flying my way,â€ a bearded Wright told me during the Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah, earlier this year. â€œPeople had their wigs blown off that I held this from them for the many months that we were working on it.â€â€œI texted him, â€™You! Before I met him, I associated the actor with the broody, bookish characters heâ€™s played on TV and film â€• like Bernard, who lives in suit vests and laboratories. On the day of our interview, Wright was nothing like Bernard. He was dressed casually in a baseball cap and unzipped jacket, puffing from a vape pen in between laughs. Weâ€™d just escaped the snow-covered sidewalks of Park City and landed comfortably inside a pop-up vodka lounge, where he was smirking at the thought of his colleaguesâ€™ â€œBernarnoldâ€ ignorance. As we sat across from each other, he took his time crafting answers to my questions, hitting each beat with a sort of temperate ease. Off-screen, it was easy to see why heâ€™s HBOâ€™s go-to guy, the kind of player who can pop in and out of any thematic narrative, molding himself into an array of dense supporting characters. â€œWestworldâ€ is Wrightâ€™s sixth project with the premium cable juggernaut, which has become the artistâ€™s de facto television home. He first appeared on the network as Martin Luther King Jr. in 2002â€™s â€œBoycott,â€ which won a Peabody Award â€œfor refusing to allow history to slip into the past.â€ Since then, HBO has refused to let Wright out of its clutches. Over the past 16 years, heâ€™s starred in the â€œAngels in Americaâ€ adaptation (2003), the R&B-fueled â€œLackawanna Bluesâ€ (2005), the Prohibition-era drama series â€œBoardwalk Empireâ€ (2013) and the Anita Hill biopic â€œConfirmationâ€ (2016). â€œHeâ€™s a world-class actor,â€ HBO Programming Chief Casey Bloys said. â€œJust on our network alone heâ€™s played MLK, heâ€™s played a gangster and heâ€™s played an empathetic robot. I donâ€™t know many actors who would be able to pull that range, not only of characters but also of tones of shows and movies. He brings this depth and humanity to his characters, and I think thatâ€™s why we continue to go back to him and why heâ€™s so in demand.â€Now heâ€™s the glue holding â€œWestworldâ€ together. And maybe, after all this time, HBO, too. On screen, Wright is the kind of performer who captures your gaze the minute he enters a frame, his deep, gravelly voice entrancing viewers into a meditative-like state. His affectations are subtle yet deliberate, like the creaking of an old wooden floor in a suspenseful thriller. Wright is, as Bloys and others have said, a first-rate actor.â€œJeffrey has this real intensity,â€ his â€œAngels in Americaâ€ co-star Mary-Louise Parker told me. â€œI have not talked to him about it, but I feel like itâ€™s largely inspired by his intellect. Their home base is Brooklyn, New York. â€œWhen we shot the film, there was what seemed like a much more productive conversation around policing and police-community relationships or justice reform or bipartisan conversation, so it was timely. But I think itâ€™s even more urgent now, because that conversation has been overshadowed by retrogressive political thinking and action, particularly through the [Department of Justice] and the attorney general,â€ he said. Wright is comfortable speaking about the current administration. He grew up in Washington, D.C., in the 1960s and â€™70s with a mother who served as a lawyer for U.S. customs for 30-plus years. (His father died when Wright was a young child.) â€œHer responsibility at headquarters was processing and assigning penalties to certain cases. If Iâ€™m not mistaken, she actually was the first black woman and second or third overall woman working for the U.S. Customs Service,â€ Wright explained during a phone call earlier this month. He happened to be with his mother at the time of our follow-up chat. He spent many hours in the hallways of her office, he recalled, doing homework and waiting for her shift to end. He became familiar with the inner workings of a government, one that he said functioned far differently than the oft-lambasted administration of today.â€œThe conversation around the nature of those who work in government has been so poisoned of late by bad-acting politicians who are actually the ones who are far more likely to be corrupt and corrupted than those who make it their lifeâ€™s work to serve the government of the United States,â€ he explained. â€œIâ€™m not saying that across the board, but it was my experience growing up.â€Wright was a staunch supporter of Barack Obama, and he campaigned for Hillary Clinton in the lead-up to the 2016 presidential election. So one doesnâ€™t have to assume what he and his mother think of the current president.â€œI can tell you this, having been in law enforcement and within the federal government for all those years, [my momâ€™s] antennas have been up for many, many months,â€ he stated. â€œThe more we learn, the more, in my case, it seems Mom is often right.â€For a long time, Wright assumed heâ€™d venture into politics, too. Theater, however, became a childhood fixation more interesting than the outside of his momâ€™s office.â€œMy mom used to take me to the theater to see the tours that would come through D.C., and I loved it. I loved it,â€ Wright remembered. â€œI was absolutely enthralled by the theater and by that world.â€œI think that informed me later, but I was afraid, in some ways, to act on it until it was too late and I couldnâ€™t resist anymore.â€ At Amherst College, Wright majored in political science and organized rallies against apartheid in South Africa. But by his third year, heâ€™d joined a theater group. After graduating with his bachelorâ€™s degree, Wright earned a scholarship to attend the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University. He dropped out after two months, but not for lack of interest. He simply realized he didnâ€™t need a teacher to tell him what he already knew.â€œI took a class in college... I think we were reading some short Chekhov plays, and I knew the first day of the class that I was going to be an actor. It was just the bizarrest thing, but it just felt like home.â€ The project that would become the spur of Wrightâ€™s career landed in his lap a few years later. Wright seared onstage. Even then, he knew it was a role that would change the course of his life.â€œIt was the ideal work for me. It was the work that I think I aspire to do and that was work that was timely and smart, that was topical and fierce, and deeply, unabashedly political. Wright has yet to see it, but heâ€™s looking forward to catching the two-part production in a different light. â€œI perceived the play, up until very recently, as being almost archival,â€ he said. â€œBut it has perhaps as great a resonance now as it did 25 years ago when we first performed it on Broadway, and that speaks to two things: It speaks to the power of Tonyâ€™s writing and his mind, but it also speaks to the unfortunate nature of the political climate that we currently find ourselves in.â€ Although Wright remains unaware of any criticism lobbed at the play back in â€™93, he understood even then that the subject matter could incite opposition. â€œAs far as the politics [of the play] go, yeah, Iâ€™m sure there were some conservatives on the right who took issue with it. I remember clearly on many nights standing there and thinking to myself that I was exactly where I was supposed to be in my life â€¦ and it was perfection. So, any criticism, any resistance meant nothing to me because we were doing what we were to be doing, and I didnâ€™t give a shit what anybody had to say about it. â€œWright went on to win the Tony Award for Best Supporting Actor in a Play and in 2003 reprised the role of Belize in Mike Nicholsâ€™ HBO adaptation. The HBO show, co-starring Parker, Meryl Streep, Al Pacino, Patrick Wilson and Emma Thompson, earned Wright an Emmy for Best Supporting Actor.The miniseries aired a year before Bloys joined HBO, first as the director of development for independent productions. â€œItâ€™s one of the reasons why I and a lot of people wanted to work here,â€ Bloys said of Wrightâ€™s performance in â€œAngels in America,â€ to be a part of â€œthat sort of groundbreaking television.â€â€œWhen I think back on the work that Iâ€™ve been able to do and the work in my career of the highest quality, a huge portion of that has been on HBO,â€ Wright told me. â€œThat didnâ€™t happen by accident.â€No, it makes sense. The type of acting he sought to do â€• â€œtimely and smart â€¦ topical and fierce â€¦ deeply, unabashedly politicalâ€ â€• required the kind of high-altitude budget and cable chutzpah HBO was willing to throw behind projects. Itâ€™s grueling, brutal. Itâ€™s intensely challenging, complicated but alive and fresh, and exists on the horizon of things that I have done in the past. So itâ€™s really where I want to be right now.â€ Back in January, Wright had just wrapped the â€œseriously ambitiousâ€ six-month shoot for â€œWestworldâ€ Season 2, which he said was equivalent to filming six feature-length films. The days were long, the content intricate and the schedule unrelenting. At times, he said, the production team had four units shooting at once (â€œon average we have two units shooting at onceâ€), barrelling their way through 15- and 16-hour days (â€œsometimes 19- to 20-hour daysâ€).â€œWeâ€™re really trying to expand whatâ€™s possible in this type of storytelling, doing it on a scale thatâ€™s epic and all on film,â€ Wright said. â€œIf anyone has the impression that itâ€™s a luxurious, glamorous process that goes into putting these things together, theyâ€™re wildly mistaken.â€The showâ€™s subject matter alone would scare some performers off. image_caption(s): â€œI was honored to be working with [Wright],â€ "Angels in America" co-star Mary-Louise Parker said. â€œEverything about it was freakishly ideal and dreamy. His whole energy is really arresting â€¦ I feel like even if he saw 10 other people perform the role, he still wouldâ€™ve found that fresh take.â€
article: When Jeffrey Wright arrived back on set six months after shooting the pilot for HBOâ€™s sci-fi series â€œWestworld,â€ he came armed with a heavy secret. Heâ€™d recently learned that his character Bernard Lowe, the reserved head of Westworldâ€™s programming division and guardian of all robots contained within the futuristic Wild-West amusement park, was an android. Like the subjects heâ€™d be monitoring throughout the seriesâ€™ first season, Bernard was not, in fact, as human as fans had been led to believe. Rather, heâ€™d been designed by Westworld mastermind Dr. Robert Ford (Anthony Hopkins) and modeled to appear like his late business partner, Arnold Weber.This colorful secret informed every morsel of Wrightâ€™s performance in Season 1, unbeknownst to his colleagues. In an early scene with Evan Rachel Wood, who plays Westworldâ€™s oldest robotic host, Dolores Abernathy, for example, a suited-up Wright calmly asks her, â€œDo you remember our last conversation, Dolores?â€ She looks at him sweetly, responding, â€œYes, of course.â€ At the time, Wood assumed this was a typical programming exchange between her character and Bernard. By the end of the season, however, the actress realized sheâ€™d been acting across multiple timelines â€• that Wright had at times been playing Bernard and at other times Arnold. Slight shifts in Wrightâ€™s personality and wardrobe, and each sceneâ€™s setting, artfully camouflaged the reveal. â€œNo one knew until they got the script of the seventh episode, and then texts were flying my way,â€ a bearded Wright told me during the Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah, earlier this year. â€œPeople had their wigs blown off that I held this from them for the many months that we were working on it.â€â€œI texted him, â€™You! You! How did you do that? How did you keep that from everyone?â€™â€ co-star Luke Hemsworth, who plays security officer Ashley Stubbs, expressively told me. â€œThere are all these little cookies and Easter eggs where you go, â€˜Oh, thatâ€™s what that isâ€™ or â€˜Thatâ€™s why Jeffreyâ€™s doing that!â€™ ... Thereâ€™s not a gesture or an eye movement that doesnâ€™t make sense when you go back and watch it again.â€ â€œIâ€™d been working with Jeffrey for half a season and I find this out, and Iâ€™m like, â€˜Did you know?!â€™â€ Wood reiterated. â€œYou find out these people who you love, who you work with every day, are holding these secrets from you!â€ Wright is good at stoking mystery. Before I met him, I associated the actor with the broody, bookish characters heâ€™s played on TV and film â€• like Bernard, who lives in suit vests and laboratories. On the day of our interview, Wright was nothing like Bernard. He was dressed casually in a baseball cap and unzipped jacket, puffing from a vape pen in between laughs. Weâ€™d just escaped the snow-covered sidewalks of Park City and landed comfortably inside a pop-up vodka lounge, where he was smirking at the thought of his colleaguesâ€™ â€œBernarnoldâ€ ignorance. As we sat across from each other, he took his time crafting answers to my questions, hitting each beat with a sort of temperate ease. Off-screen, it was easy to see why heâ€™s HBOâ€™s go-to guy, the kind of player who can pop in and out of any thematic narrative, molding himself into an array of dense supporting characters. â€œWestworldâ€ is Wrightâ€™s sixth project with the premium cable juggernaut, which has become the artistâ€™s de facto television home. He first appeared on the network as Martin Luther King Jr. in 2002â€™s â€œBoycott,â€ which won a Peabody Award â€œfor refusing to allow history to slip into the past.â€ Since then, HBO has refused to let Wright out of its clutches. Over the past 16 years, heâ€™s starred in the â€œAngels in Americaâ€ adaptation (2003), the R&B-fueled â€œLackawanna Bluesâ€ (2005), the Prohibition-era drama series â€œBoardwalk Empireâ€ (2013) and the Anita Hill biopic â€œConfirmationâ€ (2016). â€œHeâ€™s a world-class actor,â€ HBO Programming Chief Casey Bloys said. â€œJust on our network alone heâ€™s played MLK, heâ€™s played a gangster and heâ€™s played an empathetic robot. I donâ€™t know many actors who would be able to pull that range, not only of characters but also of tones of shows and movies. He brings this depth and humanity to his characters, and I think thatâ€™s why we continue to go back to him and why heâ€™s so in demand.â€Now heâ€™s the glue holding â€œWestworldâ€ together. And maybe, after all this time, HBO, too. On screen, Wright is the kind of performer who captures your gaze the minute he enters a frame, his deep, gravelly voice entrancing viewers into a meditative-like state. His affectations are subtle yet deliberate, like the creaking of an old wooden floor in a suspenseful thriller. Wright is, as Bloys and others have said, a first-rate actor.â€œJeffrey has this real intensity,â€ his â€œAngels in Americaâ€ co-star Mary-Louise Parker told me. â€œI have not talked to him about it, but I feel like itâ€™s largely inspired by his intellect. And heâ€™s not putting it on. He doesnâ€™t come in with a whole lot of need, which is really,â€ Parker paused, gathering her words, â€œI donâ€™t know, itâ€™s kind of hot,â€ she giggled over the phone. â€œHeâ€™s a super sexy guy, obviously, but you donâ€™t feel like he needs a lot from you, and he doesnâ€™t. He doesnâ€™t. But he has a bucket-load to offer both from his life experience and from his ideas.â€ That sex appeal might be hard to comprehend if youâ€™re a fan of the Jeffrey Wright whoâ€™s played Bill Murrayâ€™s mystery-obsessed neighbor in â€œBroken Flowers,â€ electricity wiz Beetee in â€œThe Hunger Gamesâ€ franchise or Bondâ€™s CIA operative pal Felix Leiter in â€œCasino Royaleâ€ and â€œQuantum of Solace.â€ The beauty of Wright, though, is his chameleon-like qualities, which allow him to be cast as a nerd in one project and a well-worn prison inmate in another. Itâ€™s why, according to him, Wright no longer auditions for parts.â€œI look at it this way: Iâ€™ve been doing this for 30 years now. If a director canâ€™t figure out what they might get from me or whether he or she wants to work with me based on what Iâ€™ve done, then I canâ€™t tell them anything more than what they donâ€™t know already.â€Another thing I learned about Wright during our Park City encounter: Heâ€™s a certified jock. He played lacrosse in college (thereâ€™s even a U.S. Lacrosse Magazine story to his name), surfs often (with a Hemsworth brother, no less) and does what most celebrities are too busy red-carpeting to do: skis when heâ€™s in Utah.â€œI skied yesterday,â€ he told me, â€œwith a woman who lives out here whoâ€™s a stunt woman on â€˜Westworldâ€™ ... she dragged me across the mountain like a rag doll.â€ Wright went on to bemoan his 52-year-old knee and praise his ski partnerâ€™s ability to eviscerate the slopes, but a quick glance at Wrightâ€™s Instagram proves his deprecation is another element of illusion.â€œIt was a big surprise to me that he surfed,â€ Luke Hemsworth said, â€œbut then I got to know him and learned he used to be a big skater. Heâ€™s like a 12-year-old grommet when heâ€™s in the surf. Heâ€™s so amped and wants to go surfing every single day, whether itâ€™s big, small, wind sideways â€• itâ€™s an infectious energy.â€Wright was at Sundance for the premiere of his film â€œMonster,â€ in which he plays the father of a teen named Steve Harmon (Kelvin Harrison Jr.), whoâ€™s wrongfully accused of a deadly crime in a Harlem bodega. The film immediately hit home for Wright, â€œas the father of a 16-year-old brown-skinned boy in New York City, in America.â€ The actor, whom Parker calls â€œa great father,â€ has two children with his ex-wife, British actress Carmen Ejogo â€• son Elijah and daughter Juno. Their home base is Brooklyn, New York. â€œWhen we shot the film, there was what seemed like a much more productive conversation around policing and police-community relationships or justice reform or bipartisan conversation, so it was timely. But I think itâ€™s even more urgent now, because that conversation has been overshadowed by retrogressive political thinking and action, particularly through the [Department of Justice] and the attorney general,â€ he said. Wright is comfortable speaking about the current administration. He grew up in Washington, D.C., in the 1960s and â€™70s with a mother who served as a lawyer for U.S. customs for 30-plus years. (His father died when Wright was a young child.) â€œHer responsibility at headquarters was processing and assigning penalties to certain cases. If Iâ€™m not mistaken, she actually was the first black woman and second or third overall woman working for the U.S. Customs Service,â€ Wright explained during a phone call earlier this month. He happened to be with his mother at the time of our follow-up chat. He spent many hours in the hallways of her office, he recalled, doing homework and waiting for her shift to end. He became familiar with the inner workings of a government, one that he said functioned far differently than the oft-lambasted administration of today.â€œThe conversation around the nature of those who work in government has been so poisoned of late by bad-acting politicians who are actually the ones who are far more likely to be corrupt and corrupted than those who make it their lifeâ€™s work to serve the government of the United States,â€ he explained. â€œIâ€™m not saying that across the board, but it was my experience growing up.â€Wright was a staunch supporter of Barack Obama, and he campaigned for Hillary Clinton in the lead-up to the 2016 presidential election. So one doesnâ€™t have to assume what he and his mother think of the current president.â€œI can tell you this, having been in law enforcement and within the federal government for all those years, [my momâ€™s] antennas have been up for many, many months,â€ he stated. â€œThe more we learn, the more, in my case, it seems Mom is often right.â€For a long time, Wright assumed heâ€™d venture into politics, too. Theater, however, became a childhood fixation more interesting than the outside of his momâ€™s office.â€œMy mom used to take me to the theater to see the tours that would come through D.C., and I loved it. I loved it,â€ Wright remembered. â€œI was absolutely enthralled by the theater and by that world.â€œI think that informed me later, but I was afraid, in some ways, to act on it until it was too late and I couldnâ€™t resist anymore.â€ At Amherst College, Wright majored in political science and organized rallies against apartheid in South Africa. But by his third year, heâ€™d joined a theater group. After graduating with his bachelorâ€™s degree, Wright earned a scholarship to attend the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University. He dropped out after two months, but not for lack of interest. He simply realized he didnâ€™t need a teacher to tell him what he already knew.â€œI took a class in college... I think we were reading some short Chekhov plays, and I knew the first day of the class that I was going to be an actor. It was just the bizarrest thing, but it just felt like home.â€ The project that would become the spur of Wrightâ€™s career landed in his lap a few years later. After working in theater â€œto build an understanding of the craft,â€ he was cast in the 1993 stage production of Tony Kushnerâ€™s Pulitzer Prize-winning play â€œAngels in Americaâ€ as charming nurse Norman â€œBelizeâ€ Arriaga and Mr. Lies. Wright seared onstage. Even then, he knew it was a role that would change the course of his life.â€œIt was the ideal work for me. It was the work that I think I aspire to do and that was work that was timely and smart, that was topical and fierce, and deeply, unabashedly political. So it was the merger of these two seemingly competing interests that Iâ€™d had growing up: theater and politics.â€œIt was also pretty damn good,â€ he added with a laugh. The complex, allegorical show about AIDS and gay culture in America during the Reagan administration is back on Broadway today, with stars Andrew Garfield, Nathan Lane, Denise Gough and Nathan Stewart-Jarrett, among others. Wright has yet to see it, but heâ€™s looking forward to catching the two-part production in a different light. â€œI perceived the play, up until very recently, as being almost archival,â€ he said. â€œBut it has perhaps as great a resonance now as it did 25 years ago when we first performed it on Broadway, and that speaks to two things: It speaks to the power of Tonyâ€™s writing and his mind, but it also speaks to the unfortunate nature of the political climate that we currently find ourselves in.â€ Although Wright remains unaware of any criticism lobbed at the play back in â€™93, he understood even then that the subject matter could incite opposition. â€œAs far as the politics [of the play] go, yeah, Iâ€™m sure there were some conservatives on the right who took issue with it. I hope they did, because it was definitely right to the jaw of the complacency and absence of empathy that the Reagan administration and conservatives applied to his response to Americans who were dying at an alarming rate from this horrible disease,â€ he said. â€œWhat I remember is being onstage at the curtain call, taking a bow with my fellow cast mates and feeling this response from people in the audience. I remember clearly on many nights standing there and thinking to myself that I was exactly where I was supposed to be in my life â€¦ and it was perfection. So, any criticism, any resistance meant nothing to me because we were doing what we were to be doing, and I didnâ€™t give a shit what anybody had to say about it. â€œWright went on to win the Tony Award for Best Supporting Actor in a Play and in 2003 reprised the role of Belize in Mike Nicholsâ€™ HBO adaptation. The HBO show, co-starring Parker, Meryl Streep, Al Pacino, Patrick Wilson and Emma Thompson, earned Wright an Emmy for Best Supporting Actor.The miniseries aired a year before Bloys joined HBO, first as the director of development for independent productions. â€œItâ€™s one of the reasons why I and a lot of people wanted to work here,â€ Bloys said of Wrightâ€™s performance in â€œAngels in America,â€ to be a part of â€œthat sort of groundbreaking television.â€â€œWhen I think back on the work that Iâ€™ve been able to do and the work in my career of the highest quality, a huge portion of that has been on HBO,â€ Wright told me. â€œThat didnâ€™t happen by accident.â€No, it makes sense. The type of acting he sought to do â€• â€œtimely and smart â€¦ topical and fierce â€¦ deeply, unabashedly politicalâ€ â€• required the kind of high-altitude budget and cable chutzpah HBO was willing to throw behind projects. But HBO profited, too. When it came time to cast recent tentpole programming â€• first the lavish period piece â€œBoardwalk Empireâ€ and then the hopeful â€œGame of Thronesâ€ replacement, â€œWestworldâ€ â€• the network turned to one of its most valuable players. If anyone was going to carry the wildly expensive, $100 million series to success, itâ€™d be Wright.And the actor was eager to do it. Heâ€™d keep the showâ€™s secrets in exchange for the opportunity to work alongside Wood, Hopkins and Thandie Newton. â€œItâ€™s,â€ he paused, inhaling his e-cigarette, â€œdeeply gratifying stuff.... Itâ€™s grueling, brutal. Itâ€™s intensely challenging, complicated but alive and fresh, and exists on the horizon of things that I have done in the past. So itâ€™s really where I want to be right now.â€ Back in January, Wright had just wrapped the â€œseriously ambitiousâ€ six-month shoot for â€œWestworldâ€ Season 2, which he said was equivalent to filming six feature-length films. The days were long, the content intricate and the schedule unrelenting. At times, he said, the production team had four units shooting at once (â€œon average we have two units shooting at onceâ€), barrelling their way through 15- and 16-hour days (â€œsometimes 19- to 20-hour daysâ€).â€œWeâ€™re really trying to expand whatâ€™s possible in this type of storytelling, doing it on a scale thatâ€™s epic and all on film,â€ Wright said. â€œIf anyone has the impression that itâ€™s a luxurious, glamorous process that goes into putting these things together, theyâ€™re wildly mistaken.â€The showâ€™s subject matter alone would scare some performers off. Here we have a futuristic theme park that functions as a source of expensive entertainment for guests who want to escape the real world and perhaps kill, befriend or romance a couple of robots â€• robots who are reaching levels of self-realization. There are graphic shootouts, metaphorical mindfucks, and, of course, HBOâ€™s typical quota of nudity. Itâ€™s thrilling yet complicated, confusing yet enlightening. Wood describes â€œWestworldâ€ as â€œintense and violentâ€ but capable of displaying these â€œincredible moments of humanity.â€ Itâ€™s those moments of humanity â€• the showâ€™s ability to be a â€œmeditation on many thingsâ€ â€• that keep Wright coming back. In fact, according to Wood, Wright describes their scenes as â€œdual meditation,â€ in which they embrace the rhythm and the tone of the content â€• content that, if he had to distill it down to its essence, is about â€œpersonal self-examination. Itâ€™s about personal awareness. Itâ€™s about our relationship to freedom or to restriction.â€ Season 2 will certainly tackle this idea of freedom and what it means to discover your personal potential. When we last left Westworld, the robots had revolted and were out for blood. In new episodes, Bernard continues to struggle with his dual identity while Dolores rallies her fellow androids for revolution. As Wood explained, â€œI had some [secrets] of my own this season, and the tables have turned for Jeffrey.â€ â€œIn some ways, the first season was really the table of contents â€” you understand who, what, where, when, when and when,â€ Wright said. â€œBut the second season makes the first season look like a kitchen drama,â€ he added, letting out a hearty laugh.Donâ€™t be fooled: Thereâ€™s much more to Wright than prestige TV. This year, in possibly his first leading film role since playing American artist Jean-Michel Basquiat in 1996â€™s â€œBasquiat,â€ Wright stars in â€œO.G.â€ as maximum-security inmate Louis, who, 24 years after committing a violent crime as a young man, finds himself on the cusp of release. His involvement with a new prisoner weeks before his departure, however, stirs up some unneeded trouble for the remorseful offender. The film, directed by Madeleine Sackler, will make its debut at this monthâ€™s Tribeca Film Festival. Wright is also set to appear in the highly anticipated film adaptation of Donna Tarttâ€™s The Goldfinch as Hobie alongside the likes of Nicole Kidman, Ansel Elgort, Luke Wilson and Sarah Paulson. (The John Crowley movie is expected to be released in October 2019.) Although heâ€™s extremely comfortable as an ensemble character at the top of HBOâ€™s roster, his star-turning role on â€œWestworldâ€ has certainly opened new doors for Wright, doors he canâ€™t even believe ever opened. â€œI remember I used to imagine the world beyond the stage â€“ backstage â€• in my little 7- or 8-year-old head,â€ Wright said. â€œNow, I realize Iâ€™ve been working as an actor for 30 years .... Itâ€™s gratifying stuff.â€

headline: North Korea Suspends Nuclear And Missile Tests: State Media
short descr: Pyongyang also said it plans to close down a former test site.
image_caption(s): North Korean dictator Kim Jong Un said the country "will join international efforts" to halt "the nuclear test altogether."
article: North Korea will suspend its nuclear and missile tests, North Korean state media reported Saturday morning local time. The Korean Central News Agency said that the country was halting nuclear tests and intercontinental ballistic missile launches as of that day, according to The Associated Press. It also plans to close down a nuclear test site in the countryâ€™s northern region. In a statement published by the state-run Korean Central News Agency, North Korean dictator Kim Jong Un promised to â€œnever use nuclear weaponsâ€ unless there is a nuclear â€œthreat or provocationâ€ to the country.â€œNorth Koreaâ€™s nuclear test center will be discarded in order to ensure the transparency of the suspension of the nuclear test,â€ the statement said.â€œThe suspension of nuclear testing is an important process for global nuclear disarmament, and the DPRK will join international efforts and efforts to halt the nuclear test altogether.â€President Donald Trump commended North Koreaâ€™s suspension of the tests in a tweet about 7 p.m. Friday EDT, calling it â€œvery good news.â€â€œNorth Korea has agreed to suspend all Nuclear Tests and close up a major test site,â€ Trump wrote.The decision comes months after tensions between the Trump administration and North Korea reached historic heights. Trump and Kim taunted each other in an exchange of tweets and official statements as North Korea test-launched several intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBM). Last year, Trump continually referred to Kim as â€œRocket Man,â€ while the dictator described Trump as a â€œmentally deranged U.S. dotard.â€In August, North Korea vowed to retaliate against the U.S. â€œthousands of times overâ€ after the United Nations Security Council imposed new sanctions against the country. Shortly after, Trump promised North Korea â€œfire and fury like the world has never seen,â€ pushing North Korea to threaten Guam, where the U.S. has a major military presence, as a potential target.The threats continued into this year as Trump and Kim argued over which countryâ€™s nuclear weapons were more powerful.Tensions between North Korea and the U.S. have eased in recent months, beginning with the Winter Olympics hosted by South Korea in Pyeongchang. North Korean and South Korean athletes marched together holding a unified flag during the Opening Ceremony at the Games. Both countries, engaged in a war for over 60 years, used the event as an opportunity to re-establish dialogue.Now Kim is scheduled to meet with South Korean President Moon Jae-in at a summit in the Demilitarized Zone next Friday. This summit would be only the third meeting of its kind between leaders of the two Koreas, according to The Guardian.Trump is also expected to meet with Kim in May or early June. He has said that he hoped to discuss denuclearizing North Korea with Kim but warned he would â€œrespectfullyâ€ walk out of the meeting if they did not.â€œThereâ€™s a bright path available to North Korea when it achieves denuclearization in a complete and verifiable and irreversible way,â€ Trump said Wednesday. â€œIt will be a great day for them. It will be a great day for the world.â€Pyongyang has made significant advancements in its nuclear and missile development programs since Trump took office last year. In July, North Korea test-launched its first ICBM, then tested a second one more than three weeks later. In total, the country fired 23 missiles during 16 tests between February and December 2017, according to a CNN count.Some experts believe that the entire continental U.S. is now within those ICBMâ€™s striking range.After meeting with North Korea in March, South Korean officials said that Kim was willing to hold talks with the U.S. about denuclearization and would suspend testing throughout negotiations.On Thursday, President Moon said North Korea has agreed to drop its long-held demand that the U.S. withdraw 28,500 U.S. troops stationed in South Korea as a condition for denuclearization.This article has been updated with background information on how tensions eased between the two countries.

headline: LA Times Union Preparing Class-Action Lawsuit Over 'Illegal Pay Disparities'
short descr: Last week, an analysis of the newsroom's pay structure revealed wide discrepancies along racial and gender lines.
image_caption(s): Los Angeles Times staffers have expressed anger and shock over recently discovered pay discrepancies at the newspaper.
article: Representatives for the Los Angeles Timesâ€™ recently unionized newsroom are readying a class-action lawsuit as a backup plan to address â€œillegal pay disparitiesâ€ at the newspaper, the union announced Friday.In an email sent to newsroom staffers, the Los Angeles Times Guild officers and bargaining committee said they had formally requested that the newspaperâ€™s leadership meet with them to grapple with recently discovered pay gaps. â€œOur immediate concern is fully addressing illegal pay disparities on an individual basis,â€ they wrote. In case the newspaperâ€™s owners decide not to engage, the committee added that it is in the process of â€œpreparing a class action lawsuit, as a second option, with assistance from the law firm that also represents the Guild.â€Last week, the union released a comprehensive analysis of the newsroomâ€™s pay structure, based upon data provided by the paperâ€™s parent company, Tronc, as a part of the collective bargaining process. The union determined that â€œTronc has underpaid women and journalists of color by thousands of dollars a year at the Los Angeles Times, suggesting systemic salary gaps by race and gender.â€The release of the report led to widespread frustration within the newsroom.â€œPeople are angry, rightfully so,â€ said one newsroom source, who added that many employees felt â€œabused and taken advantage of.â€ Just who will end up fixing the newsroomâ€™s pay structure â€• if anyone â€• remains unclear. In February, less than a month after the newsroom voted to form a union, Tronc agreed to sell the Times to health care mogul and billionaire Patrick Soon-Shiong for $500 million. The sale has yet to be finalized. In a separate email sent Friday to Times Deputy Managing Editor Colin Crawford and ccâ€™ed to Soon-Shiong, a union representative said that any ambiguity related to ownership was no excuse not to start discussions over the pay gaps. â€œIf the Employer believes its authority to negotiate over this issue may be limited because of the impending sale, we stand ready to discuss such limitations when we meet,â€ the email read in part. A Tronc spokesperson said, â€œWe at the Los Angeles Times strive to pay our employees fairly and competitively in the context of our dynamic media business. Many legitimate factors weigh into the salaries for our professional journalists, who each bring individualized talents, experiences and contributions to our news operations. We plan to evaluate the Guildâ€™s assessment of generalized pay differences in light of the realities of our news operation.â€Times Editor-in-Chief Jim Kirk did not immediately respond to a request for comment.â€œThe leadership of the LA Times, be it current owners or future, need to fix this as soon as possible,â€ said the newsroom source, adding, â€œThis newsroom is yet again in revolt.â€Here is the full email sent out to newsroom staffers on Friday: Colleagues,

headline: Film Fest Moderator Booed For Asking Michelle Pfeiffer About Her Weight
short descr: The audience ripped apart a question about actress dropping pounds for her character at a "Scarface" reunion.
image_caption(s): Michelle Pfeiffer, with Steven Bauer, director Brian De Palma and Al Pacino, received an uncomfortable question at a 35th anniversary screening of "Scarface."
article: Some members of the audience at a â€œScarfaceâ€ reunion in New York Thursday were angered by a question about Michelle Pfeifferâ€™s weight.Saying he was a parent concerned about body image, Tribeca Film Festival moderator Jesse Kornbluth asked Pfeiffer how much she weighed in the violent cult classic, according to multiple outlets.One audience member shouted, â€œWhy do you want to know?!â€ Another yelled, â€œSeriously?â€ and audible boos followed.Kornbluth tried to regain his footing by saying, â€œThis is not the question you think it is.â€Pfeiffer, who portrayed the wife of trigger-happy drug lord Tony Montana (Al Pacino), explained that she was playing a cocaine addict, so she was accelerating her weight loss to fit the story. â€œOf course, I tried to time it so that as the movie went on I became thinner and thinner and more emaciated,â€ she said. At the end of the shoot, she added, â€ I think I was living on tomato soup and Marlboros.â€Pound for pound, this had to be the most awkward moment of the night.Pfeiffer and â€œScarfaceâ€ stars Al Pacino and Steven Bauer, along with director Brian De Palma, had gathered for a 35th-anniversary screening of the movie.

headline: Daniel Craig And Rachel Weisz Expecting First Child Together

article: James Bond star Daniel Craig and wife actress Rachel Weisz are expecting a â€œlittle human.â€The two are preparing to welcome their first child together, Weisz revealed in a New York Times interview about her upcoming film â€œDisobedienceâ€ with Rachel McAdams, who reportedly gave birth to a baby of her own recently. â€œIâ€™ll be showing soon,â€ she said â€œDaniel and I are so happy. It would be like if you asked someone who just had a baby, â€˜Do you want another one that day?â€™ Theyâ€™d just go, â€˜NO!â€™â€â€œSlumdog Millionaireâ€ director Danny Boyle will helm the latest Bond adventure, which begins production at the end of the year. headline: Students From 2,600 Schools Plan Walk Outs To Protest Gun Violence
short descr: In the past few months, hundreds of thousands of young Americans have taken to the streets to demand tighter gun laws.
image_caption(s): The latest national rally comes more than a month after tens of thousands of students from some 3,000 schools participated in the #ENOUGH National School Walkout to demand that lawmakers seek tighter gun control regulations.
article: LITTLETON, Colo. (Reuters) - Colorado gun control activists rallied on Thursday near Columbine High School, calling for an end to gun violence one day before the 19th anniversary of the massacre there and a planned nationwide student walkout.The roughly 200 demonstrators who gathered in the Denver suburb of Littleton on a windy afternoon included a survivor of the Feb. 14 school shooting in Parkland, Florida that left 17 dead.The walkouts and drive to sign up voters are aimed at pressuring U.S. politicians to enact tighter restrictions on gun sales in the run-up to Novemberâ€™s mid-term congressional elections.â€œThe idea is to unite and empower survivors, to stand together,â€ said Emmy Adams, an 18-year-old senior at nearby Golden High School.On April 20, 1999 two Columbine seniors killed 12 of their classmates and a teacher before committing suicide. Since then mass shootings have occurred with shocking frequency across the United States.Among the speakers at the â€œVote for Our Livesâ€ event were Parkland High School student Carlitos Rodriguez, who told the crowd that politicians would listen if their seats were at stake.Students from more than 2,600 schools and institutions are expected to walk out of class at 10 a.m. local time on Friday, organizers say.Activists asked students to wear orange, the official color of the campaign against gun violence, and observe a 13-second silence to honor the victims killed at Columbine.Columbine has not held classes on April 20 since the massacre, a district spokeswoman said, so there would be no walkout at the school. Students were encouraged to take part in community service.The latest national rally comes more than a month after tens of thousands of students from some 3,000 schools participated in the #ENOUGH National School Walkout to demand that lawmakers seek tighter gun control regulations.It also follows â€œMarch For Our Livesâ€ rallies in cities across the United States on March 24 that were some of the biggest U.S. youth demonstrations for decades, with hundreds of thousands of young Americans and their supporters taking to the streets to demand tighter gun laws.Dudley Brown, president of the Colorado-based National Association for Gun Rights, said the gun-control movement seeks to have the government take away rights, â€œprecisely opposite of what the civil rights activists did in the 1960s.â€â€œThe main objective of these students is to ban firearms completely, and confiscate the firearms of law-abiding Americans,â€ Brown said. â€œWe will oppose them at every step.â€

headline: Lawmaker Who Blamed Storm On Jewish Bankers Takes Bizarre Trip To Holocaust Museum
short descr: Trayon White Sr. once claimed "the Rothschilds" were "controlling the climate."
image_caption(s): Halfway through a tour of the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, Trayon White Sr. left.
article: A Democratic lawmaker in Washington, D.C., who once blamed a winter storm on Jewish bankers visited the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum on Thursday.It didnâ€™t go well. According to The Washington Post, Trayon White Sr., a member of the D.C. Council, and his staff made several unusual observations about the exhibitions. Then, White abruptly left, citing an event he had to attend, only to be spotted later on the sidewalk outside the museum. During his time inside, White pointed to an image of Nazi stormtroopers surrounding a woman who was wearing a sign that read: â€œI am a German girl and allowed myself to be defiled by a Jew.â€ He asked Lynn Williams, the museumâ€™s director of leadership programs, if the stormtroopers were â€œprotecting her.â€ When told that they were forcing her to march down a street in Norden, Germany, White offered that â€œmarching is a form of protecting.â€â€œI think theyâ€™re humiliating her,â€ Williams explained, per the Post.Read the full account of the unusual visit here.White made headlines last month when he posted a video of himself blaming â€œthe Rothschildsâ€ for late-winter snow in Washington. â€œMan, it just started snowing out of nowhere this morning, man. Yâ€™all better pay attention to this climate control, man, this climate manipulation,â€ White said. â€œAnd D.C. keep talking about, â€˜We a resilient city.â€™ And thatâ€™s a model based off the Rothschilds controlling the climate to create natural disasters they can pay for to own the cities, man. Be careful.â€The wealthy banking family has been the target of anti-Semitic conspiracy theories for generations. White later apologized, reached out to Jews United for Justice and vowed to â€œcontinue to be alliesâ€ with the Jewish community. On Thursday, he didnâ€™t mention his visit to the museum on his social media accounts. However, he told the Post he planned to return.â€œThis opportunity has given me the chance to meet a lot of great Jews, a lot of people. A lot of good Jews that Iâ€™ve never had the chance to meet before,â€ White said after a long silence. â€œItâ€™s an awesome experience.â€ The rate of violence against the Jewish community in the United States has soared recently. Last year, anti-Semitic incidents jumped nearly 60 percent, with 1,986 cases over the course of the year, the Anti-Defamation League reported.

headline: California Lawmakers Consider Bill That Treats Conversion Therapy Like Consumer Fraud
short descr: The bill aims to make advertising or selling conversion therapy a fraudulent business practice.
image_caption(s): California State Assembly member Evan Low introduced a bill that seeks to make advertising conversion therapy a fraudulent business practice in California.
article: California lawmakers are considering a bill that would make selling or advertising gay conversion therapy a violation of the stateâ€™s consumer fraud laws.The state Assembly passed Bill 2943 on Thursday. The legislation, which targets the practice of trying to change a personâ€™s sexual orientation, now heads to the state Senate. If enacted, the bill would make â€œadvertising, offering to engage in, or engaging in sexual orientation change effortsâ€ to the list of fraudulent business practices already banned in California.Assemblyman Evan Low, a leader of the legislatureâ€™s LGBT Caucus, proposed the bill.â€œThis is a very personal issue to me,â€ Low said before the vote on the Assembly floor. â€œThis notion that we would accept as a legal practice that conversion therapy works is antithetical to my very existence in this body.â€Major mental health associations have thoroughly discredited conversion therapy. The American Psychological Association has said that attempts to change sexual orientation through therapy have â€œserious potential to harm young people.â€A 2012 law already bars mental health providers from attempting conversion therapy on minors, The Associated Press reported. Lowâ€™s bill seeks to offer consumer protections to adults who accuse people of defrauding them by advertising sexual orientation change efforts. Several Republican Assembly members were concerned that the bill would infringe upon the right to freedom of religion. They cited the ability of churches to sell books about conversion therapy, for example, or invite a therapist to speak about the subject at a church event. â€œThis is a bill that would be overturned by a higher court on the grounds of the First Amendment,â€ Assemblyman Matthew Harper, a Republican, said.Low said that the bill is limited to conversion therapy offered as a service in exchange for monetary compensation. He said it would not prevent people from speaking or writing on the subject, and it would not apply to the sale of books.â€œYou can still try to pray the gay away if youâ€™d like, but it hasnâ€™t proved to be effective,â€ said Assemblywoman Susan Talamantes Eggman, a Democrat who supports the bill. â€œTo advertise that you can change someoneâ€™s orientation is simply that â€” fraudulent.â€The bill has the support of the American Academy of Pediatrics, the California Psychological Association, and civil rights groups like the Human Rights Campaign. Conservative religious rights groups, such as the California Family Council and the Alliance Defending Freedom, are opposing the legislation.Low told Californiaâ€™s Assembly members on Thursday that he too had wondered if he could change his sexual orientation as a teenager. He said he ultimately suffered from depression and experienced suicidal thoughts.â€œGrowing up with so much hate, I too wanted to find out if I could be changed and if anything could work because of the societal pressures that we have,â€ he said during an emotional speech on the floor. â€œThere is nothing wrong with me. There is nothing that needs to be changed.â€CORRECTION: A previous version of this story suggested incorrectly that Assembly member Evan Low was himself a survivor of conversion therapy.
